section.title: Building θ-Alumina from Basic Crystal Data
section.para: Crystal structures are useful for many things, provided you can find them in electronic format. When you can't and are left with the bare crystallographic data in a paper things are slightly more troublesome. This was exactly my experience when working with θ-alumina -- the crystal information is readily available in Zhou and Snyder, Acta. Cryst. B, vol 47, p617 (1991), but no 3D coordinates were floating around on the interweb. Here's how I made use of it...

sect5.title: 1. Create the Unit Cell and add Symmetry Unique Atoms
sect5.para: First, we create the crystal cell in which to add our atoms. From the paper we see it is a monoclinic cell with β = 103.83°, and side lengths A = 11.854, B = 2.904, and C = 5.622 Å. You may want to zoom out afterwards to get a proper look at the new cell.

There a five symmetry-unique atoms to add into the cell, which will in turn be used to generate the remaining 35 symmetry-related atoms to give the complete unit cell. To add the atoms we will use the Add Atom method in the editing tools. Atom positions in the paper are given in fractional coordinates - we will create the atoms using these coordinates which will be converted to their 'real' equivalents by Aten (according to the current cell) as we add them.

row.entry: Add a unit cell to the model by checking the 'Has Cell?' checkbox.
Set the cell lengths A, B, and C to 11.854, 2.904, and 5.622 respectively.
Set the cell angle β to 103.83°.
On the Build toolbar change the active element to aluminium by clicking the button and selecing it in the periodic table.

sect5.title: 2. Assign the Spacegroup and Pack
sect5.para: To complete the model the spacegroup of the crystal must be set, so that generation of the symmetry-related atoms can be performed. This is all done on the Cell page. The spacegroup can be entered as either its numeric ID (as listed in the IUC Tables) or as the unformatted spacegroup name - θ-alumina belongs to spacegroup C2/m (number 12). Symmetry-related copies of the five atoms present in the cell are then generated by selecting Pack. Any overlapping atoms resulting from the application of the spacegroup's generators are automatically removed.

row.entry: Open the Cell Edit window again
Enter the spacegroup as "C2/m" or "12" and press 'Set' to assign the spacegroup to the model
Generate symmetry equivalent atoms by pressing the 'Pack' button
